sentences.text: Presidential elections will be held in Poland on {{date|2025-05-18|DMY}}. If no candidate secures more than 50% of the vote, a second round will be held on {{date|2025-06-01|DMY}}. Incumbent president Andrzej Duda is ineligible for re-election.

sentences.text: Since Tusk's rise to power, steps have been taken to deregulation|deregulate the economy, cut welfare spending and balanced budget|balance the budget. In February 2025, Tusk invited billionaire Rafa≈Ç Brzoska and Google CEO Sundar Pichai to deregulate the Polish economy and cut labor rights|labor regulations. Tusk's proposal of Brzoska has led to media labelling him as the "Polish Elon Musk". Tusk has been accused of granting Google a monopoly over the Artificial Intelligence sector in Poland via his investment agreements with Pichai.

sentences.text: The social policy of Tusk's cabinet has been seeking to expand Abortion-rights movement|abortion rights. In July 2024, the Sejm held a vote to decriminalize abortion. However, with a defection of a large section of the Polish People's Party against the government line, the vote failed and the Sejm ruled to keep abortion illegal, with 218 votes against and 215 for decriminalization.

sentences.text: S≈Çawomir Mentzen was the first candidate to begin an electoral campaign on 31 August 2024, drawing criticism and accusations of illegality from politicians of other parties for its early start. Marshal of the Sejm Szymon Ho≈Çownia from the Poland 2050 party declared his candidacy on 13 November. The Civic Coalition selected its candidate in a 2024 Civic Coalition presidential primary|presidential primary on 22 November after Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Poland)|Minister of Foreign Affairs Rados≈Çaw Sikorski challenged presumptive nominee, Mayor of Warsaw Rafa≈Ç Trzaskowski, who was the Civic Coalition's 2020 presidential candidate. Following the Civic Coalition primary, Institute of National Remembrance chairman Karol Nawrocki was endorsed by the Law and Justice party on 24 November as an officially independent candidate, as he never belonged to any political party.

On 14 March 2024, the President appointed a new composition of the National Electoral Commission (Poland)|National Electoral Commission (PKW), selected by the Sejm in December 2023. While {{ill|Sylwester Marciniak|pl|Sylwester Marciniak}} remained the chairman of the PKW, a position he held since 11 February 2020 and {{ill|Wojciech Sych|pl|Wojciech Sych}} as his deputy, seven other members were recommended by different parties in parliament: KO recommended {{ill|Konrad Sk≈Çadowski|pl|Konrad Sk≈Çadowski}} and {{ill|Ryszard Balicki|pl|Ryszard Balicki}}, PiS recommended {{ill|Miros≈Çaw Suski|pl|Miros≈Çaw Suski}} and {{ill|Arkadiusz Pikulik|pl|Arkadiusz Pikulik}}, PSL recommended {{ill|Maciej Kli≈õ|pl|Maciej Kli≈õ}}, PL2050 recommended {{ill|Pawe≈Ç Gieras|pl|Pawe≈Ç Gieras}}, and Lewica recommended Ryszard Kalisz.

sentences.text: On 29 August, the PKW ruled 5:3 to penalize PiS by refusing to return 10.8 million PLN for 36 million designated to it via party subsidy, alleging the party misused 3.6 million PLN of their provided campaign funds in the 2023 parliamentary election. Despite PiS appealing the decision to the Supreme Court of Poland|Supreme Court, the Supreme Court issued no verdict within the 60-day deadline. The party appealed to its members and supporters for financial aid in donations. The PKW tied in a vote on 23 September regarding whether the committee recognizes the Supreme Court as valid considering the ongoing Polish constitutional crisis|constitutional crisis. Further penalizations by the PKW on 18 November occurred thereafter, with the Commission ruling 5:4 to deprive PiS of its entire 75 million PLN subsidy for the three next years. PiS likewise appealed this decision to the Supreme Court, which the Supreme Court ruled invalid on 11 December, obligating the PKW to return PiS its subsidy. The Commission voted 5:4 to adjourn the meeting on 16 December without recognizing the Supreme Court or its ruling. On 30 December, a re-vote was held on the matter of whether it recognizes the Supreme Court, ruling 4:3 in favor of recognizing its verdict on this matter, and accepting the Supreme Court's decision to return the funds to PiS. Subsequently, the matter was relayed to the Ministry of Finance (Poland)|Ministry of Finance, in charge of granting subsidies.

sentences.text: In reaction to the ruling, several politicians commented. Prime Minister Donald Tusk stated on Twitter|X that he does not recognize the PKW positively ruling on granting PiS its subsidy. Marshal of the Sejm Szymon Ho≈Çownia stated the need for a compromise that lets Poles decide on a President without the validity of the president-elect's mandate being disputed by different parties. On 8 January 2025 Minister of Finance Andrzej Doma≈Ñski refused to recognize the PKW's ruling affirming PiS is to be granted its subsidy, stating the verdict was written in a "self-contradictory" way. Sylwester Marciniak, the PKW chairman, responded by stating the verdict was written clearly and demanding the Ministry grant PiS its allotted funds. Prime Minister Tusk expressed doubt over the legal validity of the PKW verdict, defending his Minister. A poll suggests 47.1% of Poles (98% of PiS voters, 71% of TD voters, 53% of Lewica voters) support PiS receiving the funds, and 46.9% (85% of PO voters, 80% of Konfederacja voters) are against.
